statement.tex: %text What positive value of $x$ makes the following pair of determinants equal? % \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 2x & 3 \\ 5 & x \end{array}\right\vert, \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 16 & 3 \\ 5 & 2 \end{array}\right\vert

step.context: %text General Question: Are the following pair of determinants equal? % \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 3 & 1 \\ 2 & 6 \end{array}\right\vert, \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 8 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right\vert
step.tex: %text Yes, they are both equal to $16$. %
%text No, this pair of determinants is unequal. %
step.reason: %text Unlike matrices, determinants with unequal elements could still be equal provided the determinant computes to the same value. So for example, % \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 3 & 1 \\ 2 & 6 \end{array}\right\vert=\left[3\times 6- 2\times 1\right]=16 \\ \left\vert\begin{array}{cc} 8 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right\vert=\left[8\times 2 - 1\times 0\right]=16 \\ %text Therefore, despite having distinct elements, the two determinants above are equal. %
